description:
Bartonella massiliensis is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Bartonella. It was first isolated from a human patient in Marseille, France, and was subsequently named Bartonella massiliensis after the city where it was discovered.

Bartonella massiliensis is a gram-negative, facultatively intracellular bacterium that is considered an emerging pathogen. It is a member of the Bartonella genus, which includes several species that can cause various human and animal diseases, such as cat-scratch disease, trench fever, and endocarditis.

The bacterium is typically transmitted by arthropod vectors, such as fleas or ticks, and can infect a range of mammalian hosts, including humans. Infection with Bartonella massiliensis can lead to a variety of clinical manifestations, including fever, lymphadenopathy, and potentially more severe complications depending on the host's immune status and the route of transmission.

Molecular and genomic studies have shown that Bartonella massiliensis is genetically distinct from other Bartonella species and represents a unique taxon within the genus. Further research is ongoing to better understand the epidemiology, pathogenesis, and clinical significance of this emerging bacterial species.
